I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At  the  request  of  the  Government  of  Mongolia,  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  for 
Reforming Higher Education for a Knowledge Society1 was included in the 2009–2012 country 
operations business plan for Mongolia.2 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) undertook a TA 
fact-finding  mission  in  February  2010,  and  agreement  was  reached  with  the  Ministry  of 
Education, Culture and Science (MECS) on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, costs and 
financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for consulting services. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Government of Mongolia considers reforming higher education as one of the key 
instruments to accelerate economic growth. The government intends to establish a higher 
education  system  that  will  meet  international  standards  by  producing  graduates  who  can 
compete successfully in an increasingly globally oriented economy. The growth of extractive 
sectors  will  provide  Mongolia  with  resources  for  further  economic  development.  However, 
without  a  well-developed  higher  education  system,  the  country's  youth  will  not  be  able  to 
compete  globally  and  the  economy  will  remain  narrowly  based.  In  February  2008,  the 
government launched a long-term National Development Strategy until 2020,3 which highlights 
the need to strengthen the country’s higher education. In 2009, the newly elected government 
emphasized  the  importance  of  developing  a  globally  competitive  education  system  for 
Mongolia's economic growth and outlined the government's priorities in education, top among 
which is the need to reform higher education. The government’s revised education sector 
master plan4 has set the twin goals of establishing a higher education system that meets 
international standards and transforms Mongolia into a knowledge economy. However, in the 
past,  the  government's  focus  on  higher  education  has  not  been  matched  by  the  funding 
necessary to undertake higher education reforms.  
3.  Changes in higher education since Mongolia began its transition to a market economy in 
early  1990s  have  included  deregulation  and  a  rapid  increase  in  private  higher  education 
institutions (HEIs), a considerable increase in student enrollments over the last 15 years, and 
significant changes in government funding. However, most of these reforms were piecemeal 
and ad hoc. Higher education net enrollment among the population in the age group of 18–24 
years is 34.9%. In 2007, 17.3% of the labor force had benefited from higher education.5 Thus, 
there is now an urgent need to undertake an extensive and systematic, yet politically feasible, 
reform of the higher education system. 
 
4.  Governance and management. By 2009, the number of HEIs increased to 146, of 
which  around  100  were  private  (some  universities'  total  student  population  is  under  100 
students),  to  the  detriment  of  the  overall  quality  of  higher  education.  Given  Mongolia’s 
population  of  2.5  million,  rationalizing  HEIs  to  improve  economies  of  scale  and  prevent 
duplication of facilities has become imperative. In 2010 the government initiated consolidation of 
HEIs by merging state-owned universities, colleges, and institutions to increase efficiency and 
economies of scale. With the newly consolidated public HEIs, the government needs support in

determining  how  to  streamline  them  in  terms  of  specializations  offered;  the  number  and 
qualifications  of  faculty;  student  transfer  mechanisms;  consolidation  of  facilities,  including 
libraries, laboratories, and other facilities; and financing and management arrangements. Other 
key challenges in governance and management include insufficient autonomy delegated to 
HEIs at the institutional level, as the government caps university fees, imposes student quotas, 
and controls governance structures. Enhancing the institutional autonomy of HEIs would require 
reassessment of the role of MECS in overseeing the higher education sector. Relatively few 
institutions provide specific management training for senior officers in HEIs.  
 
5.  Declining quality and efficiency. A university accreditation system has been in place 
since 1998; however, this system is not obligatory and is considered to be weak in terms of the 
assessments performed. The current accreditation system in Mongolia has very little effect on 
the public funding received by an institution. Since Mongolia’s economic transition began in the 
early 1990s, small private universities have proliferated, and this has often been detrimental to 
the overall quality of this subsector. To address quality and efficiency concerns, the government 
is planning to rationalize private HEIs by strengthening accreditation of private universities and 
by offering government support to the small private HEIs to convert into technical and vocational 
education and training institutions. 
 
6.  Financing of higher education. In 1994, the government began requiring public HEIs 
to charge tuition fees at levels that would cover the entire cost of academic staff salaries, thus 
generating  a  large  reduction  in  the  government’s  higher  education  budget.  However,  the 
government regulates tuition fees, and by keeping them low, prevents HEIs from accumulating 
savings. Moreover, the government is not fulfilling its legal obligation to provide public HEIs with 
sufficient recurrent funding to cover utility and operation and maintenance costs. Nor has it 
provided any policy support with regard to the "shortfall" in tuition fees. As a result, there has 
been a proliferation of private providers who have largely focused on low investment, high return 
programs, and this has led to a decline in the standard of higher education.  
 
7.  Student grants and loans. The government’s provision of grants and loans to students 
in accredited HEIs needs to be strengthened. The State Training Fund (STF) was established in 
1994 to support capable but disadvantaged students, including children of herders, orphans, 
disabled students, and students from families who have three or more children enrolled in HEIs. 
The fund is allocated annually in the national budget and is based on training area priorities 
established by MECS. However, 47% of the fund is used as scholarship support for one child of 
every civil servant, leaving insufficient funds for those identified as disadvantaged. According to 
a World Bank study, only 2% of the STF loans are paid back, and so the government is, in effect, 
subsidizing the full cost of these loans, thereby reducing the amount available for other types of 
support to HEIs. The government needs support to reform the STF to ensure its efficiency, 
transparency, and accountability.  
 
8.  University admissions and examination system. To improve the current method of 
awarding STF grants and loans, the government has made it a priority to develop a nationwide 
assessment  instrument  for  university  admissions.  This  instrument  will  be  based  on  good 
international practices for measurement and assessment of post-secondary learning, including a 
university admissions examination. In view of this reform of the university admissions process, 
the broader reform of the STF will need to be undertaken in phases. The TA will provide key 
policy recommendations on governance, management, and financing of the higher education 
sector, in addition to supporting development of a national university admissions examination.

3
9.  Higher education reforms. The government has begun reforming the institutional and 
organizational structure of HEIs by merging state-owned universities, colleges, and institutions 
to increase efficiency and economies of scale. As a result, effective 1 July 2010 the number of 
state-owned (public) universities, colleges, and institutes has been reduced from 42 to 16. The 
government  is  developing  plans  to  build  a  completely  new  university  campus  outside 
Ulaanbaatar,  designed  and  staffed  to  meet  an  acceptable  international  standard.  The 
government has established six working groups to reorganize the consolidated universities, to 
develop a higher education sector road map,6 and to guide the development of a new university 
campus.  The  government  has  requested  ADB  to  provide  support  in  developing  and 
implementing these important reforms.  
10.   ADB’s assistance to the education sector. ADB has provided assistance to basic and 
secondary education since 1991. As of December 2009, ADB had approved 4 loans amounting 
to $42.5 million, 2 Asian Development Fund grant projects totaling $27 million, plus 10 TA 
grants totaling $4.4 million, and 3 Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and Japan Fund for 
Information and Communication Technology grant projects in the amount of $5 million for the 
sector.  The  recent  country  assistance  program  evaluation  report7 on  ADB's  assistance  in 
Mongolia rated ADB's assistance in education as highly successful. Given Mongolia’s evolving 
needs, ADB’s strategies in education are shifting beyond basic education, to vocational and 
higher education to promote broad-based and inclusive growth.8  ADB is implementing a project 
preparatory TA for Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education (footnote 6), with an ensuing 
project9 scheduled for 2011 approval. This TA will be coordinated closely with the project 
preparatory TA to address urgent and priority reform areas before the start of the ensuing 
project. For instance, the reform of the STF would be an area of coordination between this TA, 
and the project preparatory TA and its ensuing project. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA is the improved quality, relevance, and management of higher 
education in Mongolia. The outcome of the TA will be a comprehensive analysis of the choices 
for improving the quality, relevance, and management of higher education in Mongolia.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The main TA output will be key policy recommendations on measures and mechanisms 
for improving higher education in Mongolia. The policy recommendations will be drawn from the 
analysis and assessment of the key issues examined in the main TA report, including (i) the 
higher  education  policy  environment  and  proposed  financing  and  governance  reforms,  (ii) 
current constraints and efficiency issues, (iii) rationalization of HEIs to ensure efficiency and 
economies of scale, (iv) strengthening the effectiveness and capacity to manage the STF and 
improving the targeting of financial assistance to disadvantaged groups, (v) development of a

nationwide assessment tool for university admissions, and (vi) capacity building for MECS staff 
and university presidents to implement higher education reforms. These policy measures and 
effective mechanisms for implementation will be identified, prioritized, and costed. The policy 
recommendations  will  also  incorporate  the  findings  of  the  project  preparatory  TA  for 
Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education.  
 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 11 months in two phases.  
 
(i)  Phase 1, lasting 6 months, will comprise: (a) reviewing higher education policies 
and strategies in Mongolia based on a rapid assessment and review of recent 
higher education policy recommendations by the World Bank, ADB, the United 
Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and other relevant organizations; (b) 
assessing the feasibility of higher education reforms currently proposed by the 
government;  (c)  identifying  challenges  and  opportunities  to  improve  HEIs, 
including a labor supply and demand analysis, economic growth projections, a 
policy analysis, and an analysis of the capacity of HEIs; (d) organizing overseas 
study  tours  to  review  effective  higher  education  models;  (e)  conducting 
multistakeholder  consultations  on  the  proposed  higher  education  reforms, 
including supporting workshops and seminars for six higher education working 
groups established by the government; (f) organizing a conference on secondary 
and  tertiary  education  reforms;  (g)  developing  and  implementing  a 
communication strategy targeted to key stakeholders about the importance and 
benefits  of  proposed  higher  education  reforms  through  advocacy  and  media 
related activities; and (h) reviewing, publishing, and disseminating the revised 
education sector master plan (footnote 4) and other relevant knowledge products.  
(ii)  Phase 2, lasting 5 months, will comprise: (a) preparing recommendations for 
financing and governance reforms in higher education, through a participatory 
approach  and  in  collaboration  with  the  ADB-financed  TA  consultants  for 
Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education; (b) preparing recommendations 
for  developing  a  university  entrance  and  high  school  graduation  exam;  (c) 
preparing recommendations for strengthening the STF; (d) organizing a series of 
stakeholder consultations in  Mongolia to share preliminary findings and develop 
the main TA report; (e) organizing a final review workshop to present key TA 
findings; (f) preparing knowledge products as discussed in para. 14; and (g) 
developing a final report.  
 
14.  Study tours will be undertaken at an early stage in TA implementation. Participants will 
be officials from the central government, including MECS senior officials and selected members 
of Parliament and university presidents who develop and implement policies relating to higher 
education. The tours will allow these key officials to (i) observe good practice in countries with 
effective  higher  education  systems  such  as  Canada,  the  People's  Republic  of  China,  the 
Republic  of  Korea,  Singapore,  or  the  United  States;10 and  (ii)  exchange  experiences  and 
lessons learned with officials from other countries. Three workshops and a conference will be 
held. The workshops will serve as a platform for (i) sharing TA findings at various stages, (ii) 
building consensus among TA stakeholders, and (iii) obtaining feedback for improving the TA 
work and findings. The workshops will be issue-oriented and are tentatively scheduled at the 
start of the TA, halfway through the TA, and towards the end of the TA. The conference will be 
held during phase 1 of the TA and will bring together international and national experts in 
secondary and tertiary education reform. The TA outputs will include the following knowledge

products: (i) a policy note presenting the key findings and major policy recommendations of the 
TA, which will be shared with decision makers at the national and local levels; (ii) an external 
publication (i.e., an article) on Mongolia's education reforms; (iii) a conference report; and (iv) 
the revised education sector master plan, which will be edited and then published.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $550,000 equivalent, of which $100,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV) and $400,000 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, funded by the 
Government of Japan. The Government of Mongolia will provide $50,000 through an in-kind 
contribution. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MECS will be the executing agency for the project. A steering committee (including 
senior officials of MECS) will provide overall guidance. Consulting services consisting of five 
international consultants for 11 person-months and four national consultants for 17.5 person-
months will be required. Consultants will have expertise in (i) higher education governance and 
management,  (ii)  higher  education  financing,  (iii)  higher  education  assessment,  (iv)  quality 
assurance, and (v) knowledge development. The consultants will be responsible for producing 
the TA’s outputs and deliverables effectively and on time, and for organizing and carrying out all 
TA activities, including the conference and the study tours. ADB will recruit an international 
knowledge development specialist and a national quality assurance specialist individually. The 
remaining consultants will be engaged through a firm in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and based on the quality of the 
proposal (80%) and the cost (20%) of the services to be provided (under the quality- and cost-
based  selection  method),  using  a  biodata  technical  proposal.  The  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. MECS will provide a suitably furnished office with utilities and 
telecommunication access (broadband internet connection), materials, data, and documents as 
required under the TA; and will cover the cost of office utilities (electricity, heating) for the 
consultants. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Consultants will be recruited 
through advance contracting to expedite TA start-up. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction; and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $100,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of 
Mongolia for Reforming Higher Education for a Knowledge Society, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of consultants for a total of 28.5 
person-months, consisting of five international consultants (11 person-months) and five national 
consultants (17.5 person-months), over a period of 11 months during TA implementation. The 
consultants will work in close consultation with the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science 
(MECS) as the executing agency, and other responsible government agencies to ensure full 
acceptance  of  the  TA  outcome.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  (i)  recruit  an 
international  knowledge  development  specialist  and  a  national  quality  assurance  specialist 
individually; and (ii) engage the remaining consultants through a firm in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and based on the 
quality of the proposal (80%) and the cost (20%) of the services to be provided (under the 
quality- and cost-based selection method), using a biodata technical proposal.  
 
2.  The consultants will produce the following in both English and Mongolian: (i) the main TA 
report, (ii) a policy note for decision makers, and (iii) a conference report. The consultants will 
have  expertise  in  (i)  higher  education  governance  and  management,  (ii)  higher  education 
financing,  (iii)  higher  education  assessment,  (iv)  quality  assurance,  and  (v)  knowledge 
development. The international higher education governance and management consultant will 
be  the  team  leader,  while  the  national  consultant  on  higher  education  governance  and 
management will be the deputy team leader. The consultants recruited through a firm are 
expected to work as a team and to report to the team leader. The consultants will deliver the 
TA’s outputs and deliverables effectively and on time, and will organize and carry out all TA 
activities. National consultants should have the relevant educational background, preferably a 
graduate degree, and at least 5 years of work experience in their field. International consultants 
should have relevant educational qualifications, preferably a graduate degree, and at least 10 
years of work experience in their field, particularly in developing countries.  
 
A.  Consulting Firm Consultants 
 
3.  Team  leader  and  higher  education  governance  and  management  specialist 
(international, 4 person-months). The specialist, who will be experienced in higher education 
management and governance in developed and developing countries, will: 
(i)  submit to MECS and ADB an inception report within 1 month after the fielding of 
the  consultants;  the  report  will  contain  (a)  a  work  plan  detailing  each  team 
member’s inputs (to be updated periodically as needed), (b) an outline of the 
main  TA  report  and  schedule,  and  (c)  the  design  and  plans  for  conducting 
workshops and a conference;  
(ii)  ensure a clear delineation of responsibilities among team members and national 
and  local  government  counterparts  in  the  preparation,  implementation,  and 
follow-up work for the desk review, reports, workshops, seminars, and other TA 
activities, including the study tours;  
(iii)  develop an overall work plan and a participation strategy for major stakeholders, 
including counterparts at the national and university levels, the private sector, as 
well as development partners;  
(iv)  undertake a desk review of recent higher education policy recommendations for 
Mongolia by the World Bank, ADB, the United Nations Development Programme 
(UNDP), and other relevant organizations; and assess the feasibility of higher 
education  reforms  currently  proposed  by  the  government,  including 
rationalization of higher education institutions (HEIs) to ensure efficiency and 
economies of scale as well as the building of a new campus outside Ulaanbaatar;

Appendix 3  11 
(v)  lead the policy dialogue on higher education with MECS and other government 
agencies, including the Ministry of Finance and local governments; and conduct 
stakeholder  consultations  and  consensus  building,  including  through  the 
Education Donors’ Consultative Mechanism;  
(vi)  prepare  a  comprehensive  assessment  of  (a)  the  higher  education  policy 
environment  and  proposed  financing  and  governance  reforms,  (b)  current 
constraints and efficiency issues, and (c) the links between higher education, 
basic and secondary education, and the labor market, taking into account the 
implications of the global economic recession for job creation and employment in 
Mongolia; 
(vii)  take the lead in (a) promoting greater government investment in research, and (b) 
building the capacity of MECS staff and university presidents to implement higher 
education reforms;  
(viii)  organize  a  conference  with  the  participation  of  leading  experts,  as  well  as 
workshops with stakeholders; 
(ix)  identify administrative, financial, and institutional constraints and opportunities in 
Mongolia’s  higher  education,  and  recommend  effective  mechanisms  to 
consolidate public institutions and rationalize private institutions;   
(x)  review  and  propose  governance  arrangements  for  public  universities  and  a 
regulatory framework for private HEIs, including government-university relations 
(autonomy and accountability), a governance structure (with university council 
functions  including  business-industry  representation),  appointment  procedures 
(university leadership, management, faculty, and administrative staff), student 
recruitment  policy  and  arrangements,  academic  decision  making  (e.g.,  study 
programs,  international  cooperation,  curriculum  content,  and  student 
assessment), and public–private partnerships; 
(xi)  introduce advanced international experience on higher education to MECS and 
other relevant higher education policy makers, compiling the materials that have 
been collected as an appendix to the final main report, with the outline of this 
appendix being presented and provided at TA inception; 
(xii)  assist MECS in identifying countries for the study tours;  
(xiii)  propose an institutional capacity development plan for MECS and universities 
with special reference to strategic planning and monitoring and evaluation, based 
on an assessment of MECS’s capacity for policy planning in higher education; 
(xiv)  ensure that there is a clear link between the TA and the ADB-financed project 
preparatory TA for Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education;1  
(xv)  ensure that the TA incorporates the findings of a gender analysis of the higher 
education sector (linked to gender analysis of the labor market) to be undertaken 
under the TA for Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education; 
(xvi)  prepare a section on higher education management and governance for the main 
TA report;  
(xvii)  guide  the  work  of  the  communications  team  in  preparing  communication 
packages targeted at specific groups and stakeholders;  
(xviii)  prepare and ensure the quality of the final TA report; and  
(xix)  prepare, on the basis of the main TA report, (a) a concise executive summary 
focusing  on  key  findings  and  policy  recommendations,  (b)  a  policy  note  for 
decision makers, and (c) a conference report.  
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education. Manila.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
4.  Deputy  team  leader  and  specialist  on  higher  education  governance  and 
management (national, 4 person-months). The deputy team leader, who will be experienced in 
higher education management and governance in developed and developing countries, will: 
(i)  coordinate with the team leader in undertaking the tasks and responsibilities 
listed above;  
(ii)  take  responsibility  for  the  timely  and  effective  organization  of  seminars, 
workshops, and the conference; and  
(iii)  act as team leader when the team leader is not in the field. 
 
5.  Higher  education  assessment  specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The 
specialist,  who  will  be  experienced  in  higher  education  assessment  in  developed  and 
developing countries, will: 
(i)  review university admissions practices and the status of university-level student 
assessments in Mongolia, including capacity and constraints, and recommend 
assessment tools based on good international practices (particularly in middle-
income countries) for measurement and assessment of post-secondary learning, 
including a university admissions examination;  
(ii)  conduct policy dialogue with MECS senior staff and other stakeholders, including 
the Ministry of Finance, university rectors, and faculty, on the best assessment 
instrument;  
(iii)  work with MECS staff and the national higher education assessment specialist to 
develop and pilot an agreed-upon assessment tool for university admissions and 
high school graduation;  
(iv)  assess the capacity-building needs of MECS for university student assessment, 
including needs arising from the desk review, study tours, and other TA activities, 
and propose capacity-building plans to mitigate the constraints;  and  
(v)  assist the team leader to prepare and finalize the main report and other reports, 
and to prepare and participate in the workshops and the conference.  
 
6.  Higher education assessment specialist (national, 4.5 person-months). The specialist, 
who will be experienced in higher education assessment, will assist the international higher 
education assessment specialist in undertaking the tasks and responsibilities listed above.  
 
7.  Higher education financing specialist (international, 2 person-months). This specialist, 
who will be experienced in higher education financing in developed and developing countries, 
will: 
(i)  prepare a comprehensive assessment of the current financing mechanisms and 
arrangements in Mongolia's higher education, including a desk review of higher 
education recommendations by the World Bank, ADB, UNDP, and other relevant 
organizations;  
(ii)  review and propose financing arrangements for public universities;  
(iii)  identify challenges and opportunities to improve HEIs;  
(iv)  provide guidance to (a) ensure access to higher education for disadvantaged 
groups, (b) improve targeting mechanisms in higher education scholarships, and 
(c) improve efficiency and effectiveness in higher education;  
(v)  review the government's proposals to improve the use of the STF and prepare 
recommendations for reforming the STF;  
(vi)  review the government's proposal to consolidate state-owned universities and 
rationalize private universities, and assess the feasibility (including a cost-benefit 
analysis) of this proposal, focusing on the resources required under the new, 
consolidated system;

Appendix 3  13 
(vii)  together with the project preparatory TA consultants, review the government's 
proposal to build a new university campus and assess the feasibility (including a 
cost-benefit  analysis)  of  this  proposal  as  well  as  develop  alternative 
recommendations;  
(viii)  ensure that the TA incorporates findings of a gender analysis of the higher 
education sector (linked to gender analysis of the labor market) to be undertaken 
under the TA  for Strengthening Higher and Vocational Education; and 
(ix)  assist the team leader to prepare and finalize the main report and other reports, 
and to prepare and participate in the workshops and conference. 
 
8.  Higher  education  financing  specialist (national, 3 person-months). The specialist, 
who will be experienced in higher education management and governance, will assist the 
international higher education financing specialist in undertaking the tasks and responsibilities 
listed above. 
 
9.  Quality assurance specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). This specialist, who 
will be experienced in quality assurance and accreditation of higher education institutions, will: 
(i)  assess constraints in the quality assurance and accreditation of higher education 
institutions in Mongolia;  
(ii)  propose quality assurance arrangements for public universities; 
(iii)  draft  a  plan  for  developing  institutional  capacity  for  quality  assurance  and 
accreditation functions for higher education, with special reference to quality 
assurance mechanisms and organizations at MECS and public universities;  
(iv)  coordinate  stakeholder  participation  and  develop  a  sense  of  ownership  and 
commitment to the outcome among stakeholders;  
(v)  prepare  and  deliver  capacity  building  workshops  to  MECS  and  relevant 
stakeholders on quality assurance;  
(vi)  assist the team leaders to prepare and finalize the main report and other reports, 
and to prepare and participate in the workshops and conference.  
 
10.  Advocacy and communication specialist (national, 1 person-month). This specialist 
will  be  experienced  in  developing  advocacy,  communication,  and  marketing  campaigns 
including multimedia materials for Mongolia’s education sector. The specialist will: 
(i)  in consultation with the team leader and the team members, be responsible for 
identifying  key  stakeholders  in  the  area  of  higher  education  reform  and 
conducting stakeholder analysis;  
(ii)  for  each  identified  group  of  stakeholders,  identify  their  key  interest(s),  their 
perceptions of higher education problems, resources, and mandates; 
(iii)  design a series of targeted communication strategies/messages/programs for 
key stakeholder groups, identify appropriate communications channels/medium, 
and prepare related information and media materials; 
(iv)  mobilize  media  on  higher  education  reform  in  cooperation  with  project 
consultants;  advise  MECS  on  advocacy  and  communication  interventions; 
prepare communication strategies and programs to support higher education 
reforms; and identify the most appropriate means of communication (TV, radio, 
newspaper, other) for various stakeholders and develop specific communication 
packages, including mass media packages;  
(v)  disseminate  communication  packages  through  appropriate  media  (TV,  radio, 
newspaper, etc.) and monitor effectiveness of communication messages;

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(vi)  assist the team leader and deputy team leader to prepare and finalize the main 
report and other reports, and to prepare and participate in the workshops and 
conference.  
 
B.  Individual Consultants 
 
11.  Knowledge development specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). The specialist 
will  be  experienced  in  educational  reforms  in  developing  countries  and  in  developing  and 
publishing education-related knowledge products. The consultant will have at least 3 years of 
experience in Mongolia's education sector, and will be familiar with reforms in basic, secondary, 
and higher education. The specialist will: 
(i)  in coordination with other consultants and in consultation with MECS, review 
available  studies,  reports,  and  publications  on  Mongolia's  education  sector 
prepared by the government and development organizations since 2007; 
(ii)  assist MECS in editing and publishing the revised Education Sector Master Plan 
2010–2020; 
(iii)  propose knowledge products focusing on Mongolia's experience in educational 
development,  including  basic  and  higher  education  for  national  and  possibly 
international audiences;  
(iv)  in  consultation  with  ADB,  prepare  a  series  of  knowledge  products  for 
dissemination among the stakeholders and the general public through a variety 
of  media  including  websites,  printed  materials,  and  presentations  during 
conferences;  
(v)  recruit a research consultant to assist with the assignment as needed; and 
(vi)  prepare an external publication (e.g., an article or book) on Mongolia's education 
reform.  
 
12.  Quality assurance specialist (national, 5 person-months). This specialist, who will be 
experienced  in  higher  education  reform,  including  quality  assurance  of  higher  education 
institutions,  will  assist  the  international  consultant  in  undertaking  his/her  tasks  and 
responsibilities.
